message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Behavioural ecology at the spatial–social interface
Paper Abstract: ABSTRACT Spatial and social behaviour are fundamental aspects of an animal's biology, and their social and spatial environments are indelibly linked through mutual causes and shared consequences. We define the ‘spatial–social interface’ as intersection of social and spatial aspects of individuals' phenotypes and environments. Behavioural variation at the spatial–social interface has implications for ecological and evolutionary processes including pathogen transmission, population dynamics, and the evolution of social systems. We link spatial and social processes through a foundation of shared theory, vocabulary, and methods. We provide examples and future directions for the integration of spatial and social behaviour and environments. We introduce key concepts and approaches that either implicitly or explicitly integrate social and spatial processes, for example, graph theory, density‐dependent habitat selection, and niche specialization. Finally, we discuss how movement ecology helps link the spatial–social interface. Our review integrates social and spatial behavioural ecology and identifies testable hypotheses at the spatial–social interface.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Habitat selection"

Links: [{"title":"Habitat-selection hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habitat-selection_hypothesis"},{"title":"Resource selection function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resource_selection_function"},{"title":"Isodar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isodar"}]

Here are the search results for "Habitat selection":

## Overview

Habitat selection describes how an organism's habitat in a juvenile life stage affects their behavior in their adult life.

## Resource Selection Functions

Resource selection functions (RSFs) are a class of functions used in spatial ecology to assess which habitat characteristics are important to a specific population or species of animal, by assessing a probability of that animal using a certain resource proportional to the availability of that resource in the environment.

## Isodar Theory

Isodar is a theory of habitat selection in population biology proposed by Douglas W. Morris, which underscores the importance of abundance and competition between members of the same species in selecting habitats.(no content)Isodars model density-dependent habitat selection for one or two species in two habitats according to the ideal free and ideal despotic distributions.

The search results provide information on habitat selection across ecology and population biology, including theoretical frameworks and mechanisms animals use to choose where to live.

Habitat selection describes how an organism's habitat in a juvenile life stage affects their behavior in their adult life.

## Resource Selection Functions

Resource selection functions (RSFs) are a class of functions used in spatial ecology to assess which habitat characteristics are important to a specific population or species of animal, by assessing a probability of that animal using a certain resource proportional to the availability of that resource in the environment.

## Isodar Theory

Isodar is a theory of habitat selection in population biology proposed by Douglas W. Morris, which underscores the importance of abundance and competition between members of the same species in selecting habitats.(no content)Isodars model density-dependent habitat selection for one or two species in two habitats according to the ideal free and ideal despotic distributions.

The search results provide information on habitat selection across ecology and population biology, including theoretical frameworks and mechanisms animals use to choose where to live.

Based on the web search results, here's information about spatial behavior:

## Overview

Spatial behavior refers to how organisms move through and interact with physical space. The search results highlight several contexts in which spatial behavior is studied:

### In Animal Behavior

Spontaneous Alternation Behavior (SAB) describes a research subject's tendency to pursue different stimuli in consecutive trials, despite a lack of training or reinforcement. The behavior emerged from experiments using animals (mainly rodents) who naturally demonstrated the behavioral pattern when placed in previously unexplored maze shapes, such as using T- or Y-mazes.(no content)Estes and Schoeffler proposed in 1955 that SAB originated as an adaptive behavior which enabled animals to gather information related to the distribution of resources needed for survival, such as food and shelter.

### In Human Cognition and Behavior

Spatial cognition can be seen from a psychological point of view, meaning that people's behaviour within that space is key.(no content)When people behave in space, they use cognitive maps, the most evolved form of spatial cognition, in which information about landmarks and the routes between landmarks are stored and used.

### Spatial Abilities

Spatial ability or visuo-spatial ability is the capacity to understand, reason, and remember the visual and spatial relations among objects or space.(no content)Visual-spatial abilities are used for everyday use from navigation, understanding or fixing equipment, understanding or estimating distance and measurement, and performing on a job.

Links: [{"title":"Population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics"},{"title":"Pest insect population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pest_insect_population_dynamics"},{"title":"Population dynamics of fisheries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics_of_fisheries"},{"title":"Population model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_model"},{"title":"Population ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology"},{"title":"Matrix population models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_population_models"},{"title":"Source–sink dynamics","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source–sink_dynamics"},{"title":"Malthusian growth model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malthusian_growth_model"},{"title":"Metapopulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metapopulation"},{"title":"León Mario Bedoya - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le%C3%B3n_Mario_Bedoya"}]

Here are the search results for "Population dynamics":

## Definition and Overview

Population dynamics is the type of mathematics used to model and study the size and age composition of populations as dynamical systems.(no content)Population dynamics is a branch of mathematical biology, and uses mathematical techniques such as differential equations to model behaviour.

More broadly, population dynamics describes the ways in which a given population grows and shrinks over time, as controlled by birth, death, and migration.

## Key Variables

Simplified population models usually start with four key variables (four demographic processes) including death, birth, immigration, and emigration.

## Historical Development

The beginning of population dynamics is widely regarded as the work of Malthus, formulated as the Malthusian growth model.(no content)Benjamin Gompertz and Pierre François Verhulst in the early 19th century refined and adjusted the Malthusian demographic model.

## Applications

Population dynamics has numerous practical applications, including:

- Understanding changing fishery patterns and issues such as habitat destruction, predation and optimal harvesting rates
- Determining maximum harvest for agriculturists, understanding the dynamics of biological invasions, and for environmental conservation
- Control theory applications, evolutionary game theory in industrial MIMO systems, military campaigns, water distribution, and dispatch of distributed generators

I've completed a web search for "Graph theory" and retrieved comprehensive information about the subject. Here's what I found:

## Overview

In mathematics and computer science, graph theory is the study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects.(no content)A graph in this context is made up of vertices (also called nodes or points) which are connected by edges (also called arcs, links or lines).

## Historical Background

The paper written by Leonhard Euler on the Seven Bridges of Königsberg and published in 1736 is regarded as the first paper in the history of graph theory.

## Applications

Graph theory has numerous practical applications across various fields:

- **Chemistry**: In chemistry a graph makes a natural model for a molecule, where vertices represent atoms and edges bonds.
- **Computer Networks**: Graph theory plays an important role in electrical modeling of electrical networks, here, weights are associated with resistance of the wire segments to obtain electrical properties of network structures.
- **Social Networks**: Graph theory is also widely used in sociology as a way, for example, to measure actors' prestige or to explore rumor spreading, notably through the use of social network analysis software.
- **Biology**: Graph theory is useful in biology and conservation efforts where a vertex can represent regions where certain species exist (or inhabit) and the edges represent migration paths or movement between the regions.
- **Navigation**: Such weighted graphs are commonly used to program GPS's, and travel-planning search engines that compare flight times and costs.

I've completed a web search for "Graph theory" and retrieved comprehensive information about the subject. Here's what I found:

## Overview

In mathematics and computer science, graph theory is the study of graphs, which are mathematical structures used to model pairwise relations between objects.(no content)A graph in this context is made up of vertices (also called nodes or points) which are connected by edges (also called arcs, links or lines).

## Historical Background

The paper written by Leonhard Euler on the Seven Bridges of Königsberg and published in 1736 is regarded as the first paper in the history of graph theory.

## Applications

Graph theory has numerous practical applications across various fields:

- **Chemistry**: In chemistry a graph makes a natural model for a molecule, where vertices represent atoms and edges bonds.
- **Computer Networks**: Graph theory plays an important role in electrical modeling of electrical networks, here, weights are associated with resistance of the wire segments to obtain electrical properties of network structures.
- **Social Networks**: Graph theory is also widely used in sociology as a way, for example, to measure actors' prestige or to explore rumor spreading, notably through the use of social network analysis software.
- **Biology**: Graph theory is useful in biology and conservation efforts where a vertex can represent regions where certain species exist (or inhabit) and the edges represent migration paths or movement between the regions.
- **Navigation**: Such weighted graphs are commonly used to program GPS's, and travel-planning search engines that compare flight times and costs.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about ecological niche:

## Definition

In ecology, a niche is the match of a species to a specific environmental condition.(no content)It describes how an organism or population responds to the distribution of resources and competitors (for example, by growing when resources are abundant, and when predators, parasites and pathogens are scarce) and how it, in turn, alters those same factors (for example, limiting access to resources by other organisms, acting as a food source for predators and a consumer of prey).

## Key Concepts

There are several important types of ecological niches:

- **Fundamental vs. Realized Niche**: An organism free of interference from other species could use the full range of conditions (biotic and abiotic) and resources in which it could survive and reproduce which is called its fundamental niche. However, as a result of pressure from, and interactions with, other organisms (i.e. inter-specific competition) species are usually forced to occupy a niche that is narrower than this, and to which they are mostly highly adapted; this is termed the realized niche.

- **Grinnellian Niche**: A Grinnellian niche is determined by the habitat in which a species lives and its accompanying behavioral adaptations.

- **Eltonian Niche**: An Eltonian niche emphasizes that a species not only grows in and responds to an environment, it may also change the environment and its behavior as it develops.

## Historical Context

The term was coined by the naturalist Roswell Hill Johnson but Joseph Grinnell was probably the first to use it in a research program in 1917, in his paper "The niche relationships of the California Thrasher".

Links: [{"title":"Social behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_behavior"},{"title":"Social and behavior change communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_and_behavior_change_communication"},{"title":"Social Behavior and Personality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Behavior_and_Personality"},{"title":"Journal of Health and Social Behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Health_and_Social_Behavior"},{"title":"Journal for the Theory of Social Behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_for_the_Theory_of_Social_Behaviour"},{"title":"Anti-social behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-social_behaviour"},{"title":"Social behavior in education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_behavior_in_education"},{"title":"Genetics of social behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics_of_social_behavior"},{"title":"Anti-social Behaviour Act 2003 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-social_Behaviour_Act_2003"},{"title":"Cyberpsychology, Behavior, and Social Networking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyberpsychology,_Behavior,_and_Social_Networking"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about social behavior:

## Definition and Basic Concepts

Social behavior is behavior among two or more organisms within the same species, and it encompasses any behavior in which one member affects another.(no content)Social behavior can be seen as similar to an exchange of goods, with the expectation that when you give, you will receive something similar in return.

## How Social Behavior is Determined

The dual-systems model of reflective and impulsive determinants of social behavior came out of the realization that behavior cannot just be determined by one single factor. Instead, behavior can arise by those consciously behaving (where there is an awareness and intent), or by pure impulse.

## Types of Social Behavior

Mundane social behavior is a result of interactions in day-to-day life, and are behaviors learned as one is exposed to those different situations.(no content)On the other hand, defensive behavior arises out of impulse, when one is faced with conflicting desires.

## Development Over Time

Social behavior constantly changes as one continues to grow and develop, reaching different stages of life. The development of behavior is deeply tied with the biological and cognitive changes one is experiencing at any given time.(no content)Culture (parents and individuals that influence socialization in children) play a large role in the development of a child's social behavior.

## Biological Factors

Lesions in the prefrontal cortex that occurred in adulthood can affect the functioning of social behavior. When these lesions or a dysfunction in the prefrontal cortex occur in infancy/early on in life, the development of proper moral and social behavior is affected and thus atypical.

Links: [{"title":"Behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Human behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_Ecology_and_Sociobiology"},{"title":"Behavioral Ecology (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_Ecology_(journal)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:United States Education Program/Courses/Behavioral Ecology (Joan Strassmann)/Syllabus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:USEP/Courses/Behavioral_Ecology_(Joan_Strassmann)/Syllabus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wiki Ed/Duke University/Behavioral Ecology - Bio 267 (Spring 2017) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wiki_Ed/Duke_University/Behavioral_Ecology_-_Bio_267_(Spring_2017)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:United States Education Program/Courses/Behavioral Ecology (Joan Strassmann)/Assignment 7 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:United_States_Education_Program/Courses/Behavioral_Ecology_(Joan_Strassmann)/Assignment_7"},{"title":"Adaptive behavior (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_behavior_(ecology)"},{"title":"Wikipedia:United States Education Program/Courses/Behavioral Ecology (Joan Strassmann)/2014 Syllabus - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:United_States_Education_Program/Courses/Behavioral_Ecology_(Joan_Strassmann)/2014_Syllabus"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wiki Ed/Duke University/Bio 267 - Behavioral Ecology (Fall 2018) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wiki_Ed/Duke_University/Bio_267_-_Behavioral_Ecology_(Fall_2018)"}]

## Behavioral Ecology

Behavioral ecology, also spelled behavioural ecology, is the study of the evolutionary basis for animal behavior due to ecological pressures.(no content)It is a major subfield of both ecology and evolutionary biology that incorporates ecological and evolutionary principles to analyze the ways in which animal behavior has evolved, and the ways in which animals use behavior to solve social and ecological problems.

### Origins and Framework

Behavioral ecology emerged from ethology after Niko Tinbergen outlined four questions to address when studying animal behaviors: what are the proximate causes, ontogeny, survival value, and phylogeny of a behavior?

### Key Concepts

**Adaptive Significance:** If an organism has a trait that provides a selective advantage in its environment, then natural selection favors it. Adaptive significance refers to the expression of a trait that affects fitness, measured by an individual's reproductive success.

**Adaptive Behavior:** In behavioral ecology, adaptive behavior is any behavior that contributes directly or indirectly to an individual's reproductive success, and is thus subject to the forces of natural selection.

### Major Areas of Study

The field covers several important topics, including:
- Parental care, which is the investment a parent puts into their offspring. There is great variation in parental care in the animal kingdom, with some species exhibiting no parental care while others exhibit single-parental or bi-parental care.
- The evolution of aggression, mating behavior, parental care, communication, and the complexities of living in groups and families.

Human behavioral ecology also applies these principles to humans, examining adaptive design within ecological contexts.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Pathogen transmission"

Links: [{"title":"Pathogen transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_(medicine)"},{"title":"Pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathogen"},{"title":"Blood-borne disease - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blood-borne_disease"},{"title":"Reverse zoonosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_zoonosis"},{"title":"Cholera - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cholera"},{"title":"Typhoid fever - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Typhoid_fever"},{"title":"Human pathogen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_pathogen"},{"title":"Airborne transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airborne_transmission"},{"title":"Sociality and disease transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociality_and_disease_transmission"},{"title":"Threshold host density - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threshold_host_density"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about pathogen transmission:

## Routes of Transmission

Transmission of pathogens can occur by direct contact, through contaminated food, body fluids or objects, by airborne inhalation or through vector organisms.

### Direct and Indirect Routes

Transmission can be indirect, via another organism, either a vector (e.g. a mosquito or fly) or an intermediate host (e.g. tapeworm in pigs can be transmitted to humans who ingest improperly cooked pork).(no content)Indirect contact transmission, also known as vehicle-borne transmission, involves transmission through contamination of inanimate objects. Vehicles that may indirectly transmit an infectious agent include food, water, biologic products such as blood, and fomites such as handkerchiefs, bedding, or surgical scalpels.

### Airborne Transmission

Smaller droplets and aerosols contain live infectious agents, and can remain in the air longer and travel farther.(no content)Common infections that spread by airborne transmission include SARS-CoV-2; measles morbillivirus, chickenpox virus; Mycobacterium tuberculosis, influenza virus, enterovirus, norovirus and less commonly other species of coronavirus, adenovirus, and possibly respiratory syncytial virus.

### Fecal-Oral Route

In the fecal-oral route, pathogens in fecal particles pass from one person to the mouth of another person. Fecal–oral transmission is primarily considered as an indirect contact route through contaminated food or water.

## Transmissibility and Key Concepts

Transmissibility is the probability of an infection, given a contact between an infected host and a noninfected host.(no content)The term infectivity describes the ability of an organism to enter, survive and multiply in the host, while the infectiousness of a disease agent indicates the comparative ease with which the disease agent is transmitted to other hosts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Ran Nathan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ran_Nathan"}]

Based on the search results, I now have comprehensive information about movement ecology. Let me provide a detailed answer.

## Movement Ecology

Movement ecology emerged as a field of research in 2002, when researcher Ran Nathan recognized that different movement phenomena were studied in isolation from each other and wondered why there was still no general unifying theory of organismal movement.(no content)In 2006, Nathan initiated and led an international group at the Israel Institute for Advanced Studies in Jerusalem which set the foundation for development of movement ecology as a new integration of movement research.(no content)Movement ecology encompasses various aspects including dispersal (and long-distance dispersal in particular), migration, foraging, navigation, flight aerodynamics, animal behavior, social interactions, invasive species, disease spread by avian species, gene flow, plant-animal interactions and plant recruitment.(no content)In 2013, a major forum for publishing studies on the movement of animals and plants was established through the open-access journal Movement Ecology (BioMed Central).

The field integrates research on the movement patterns of both animals and plants, seeking to understand the mechanisms and ecological consequences of how organisms move through space and time.

Links: [{"title":"Environmental movement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_movement"},{"title":"Ecological Movement of Thessaloniki - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_Movement_of_Thessaloniki"},{"title":"Deep ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_ecology"},{"title":"Cyprus Social Ecology Movement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyprus_Social_Ecology_Movement"},{"title":"Environmentalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmentalism"},{"title":"Migration (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Migration_(ecology)"},{"title":"Independent Ecological Movement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_Ecological_Movement"},{"title":"Ecological Party of Uzbekistan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_Movement_of_Uzbekistan"},{"title":"Ecological Movement of Romania - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_Movement_of_Romania"},{"title":"Ecological Movement of Moldova - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_Movement_of_Moldova"}]

The search results returned information about environmental and ecological movements (social/political movements), but not "movement ecology" as a scientific field. Let me search more specifically for the scientific discipline.

Links: [{"title":"Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology"},{"title":"Behavioral ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology"},{"title":"Animal migration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_migration"},{"title":"Ethology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethology"},{"title":"Margaret Crofoot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Crofoot"},{"title":"Neuroethology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuroethology"},{"title":"Conservation behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_behavior"},{"title":"Animal Behaviour (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_Behaviour_(journal)"},{"title":"Deep ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_ecology"},{"title":"Animal behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_behaviour"}]

Let me search more specifically for "movement ecology" as a field of study.

Links: [{"title":"Ran Nathan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ran_Nathan"}]

Great! Now I have specific information about movement ecology. Let me search for more detailed information about what movement ecology encompasses.

Links: [{"title":"Ran Nathan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ran_Nathan"}]

Based on the search results, I now have comprehensive information about movement ecology. Let me provide a detailed answer.

## Movement Ecology

Movement ecology emerged as a field of research in 2002, when researcher Ran Nathan recognized that different movement phenomena were studied in isolation from each other and wondered why there was still no general unifying theory of organismal movement.(no content)In 2006, Nathan initiated and led an international group at the Israel Institute for Advanced Studies in Jerusalem which set the foundation for development of movement ecology as a new integration of movement research.(no content)Movement ecology encompasses various aspects including dispersal (and long-distance dispersal in particular), migration, foraging, navigation, flight aerodynamics, animal behavior, social interactions, invasive species, disease spread by avian species, gene flow, plant-animal interactions and plant recruitment.(no content)In 2013, a major forum for publishing studies on the movement of animals and plants was established through the open-access journal Movement Ecology (BioMed Central).

The field integrates research on the movement patterns of both animals and plants, seeking to understand the mechanisms and ecological consequences of how organisms move through space and time.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors and rerun validation until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Behavioural ecology at the spatial–social interface". Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Key Findings:**
- The paper is a **survey** (literature review integrating existing work on spatial and social behavioral ecology)
- Extracted **10 key triples** representing fundamental concepts, methods, and tasks in the field
- All triples classified as either "uses" relations (since it's a survey building on existing work)

**Triples Identified:**
1. **Behavioral ecology** (concept) - The core field being surveyed
2. **Animal behavior** (concept) - Fundamental subject matter
3. **Social behavior** (concept) - One dimension of the spatial-social interface
4. **Spatial cognition** (concept) - How organisms perceive space
5. **Transmission (medicine)** (task) - Pathogen transmission affected by spatial-social interactions
6. **Population dynamics** (concept) - Ecological process affected by the interface
7. **Graph theory** (method) - Approach for modeling networks of spatial-social interactions
8. **Habitat-selection hypothesis** (concept) - Mechanism linking spatial distribution with social factors
9. **Ecological niche** (concept) - Niche specialization integrating spatial-social processes
10. **Animal migration** (concept) - Connects to movement ecology framework

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed

The triples_output.json file has been updated with complete metadata including Wikipedia URLs and relevance descriptions for each entity.

Sources:
- [Behavioral ecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavioral_ecology)
- [Social behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_behavior)
- [Spatial cognition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_cognition)
- [Transmission (medicine)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_(medicine))
- [Population dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics)
- [Graph theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory)
- [Habitat-selection hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habitat-selection_hypothesis)
- [Ecological niche](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_niche)
- [Animal migration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_migration)
